Re: Why is the military allowed to discriminate against allowing type 1 diabetics to join

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎10-10-2012 06:45 PM

Pam,

 

That NBA arguement is weak at best. Chris Paul, Spud Webb, Mugsey Boges, all were way shorter than the average height in the NBA. The reason these players were able to play in the NBA is because they had the skill to do so.

 

I have the skills and abilities to serve my country no matter what if I am a diabetic or if i were short. And the little statement about making your child feel normal by not referring to others as normal is stupid as well. The government (in way of policies and discrimination) are the ones that determine who is normal and who is not. We see it all the time. Blaming a parent is even weaker than the NBA arguement.

‎10-10-2012 11:54 PM

Actually, since effective treatment of diabetes did not exist at the time of the revolutionary war, this argument is not valid, diabetes was a death sentence back then.
Adult onset Type 1 since 4-28-2006

Re: Why is the military allowed to discriminate against allowing type 1 diabetics to join

‎10-11-2012 12:35 AM

This seems to be a source of debate, I for one can see both sides of the argument. I spent eight years active duty and it was one of the best decisions I ever made, absolutely loved it. But I honesty have to say, there is no way I could have been a effective as I was if I was diabetic when I joined, had they allowed it.
As far as allowing someone to stay after diagnosis, they only do so if you can demonstrate you can, and to the best of my knowledge, it is only if you have been in for over ten years. And then you will be medically retired at the twenty year mark.
The Sargent that served in Iraq was a one time exception, but very well may be the beginning of the next chapter, so by all means, keep up the fight.
He was in year fourteen when diagnosed, and if we keep watching his career, I bet he retires at twenty.
Adult onset Type 1 since 4-28-2006

Re: Why is the military allowed to discriminate against allowing type 1 diabetics to join

‎10-11-2012 01:25 AM

That is my point. No effective treatment for the men who fought in the Revolutionary War, but they fought anyway. Many volunteered. Those were the days of true freedom. This arguement is very valid. I, like my forefathers, would like to excercise my right to decide what i do with my life. There are many jobs in the military that do not put folks in harms way. So the arguement that all diabetics should be banned from service is a lame excuse. I was diagnosed in June of 1999, after being a diabetic since at least the end of Jan 99. I went 5-6 months with no insulin. I lost 40 lbs and argued with my doctor on being admitted to the hospital. She wanted me to stay for 3 days. I gave her 1 night and 1 day. i know myself better than those who don't even have the disease. I know what I can and cannot do, not some desk jockey in D.C. making decisions on what could maybe happen. I know if i can perform the duties described. No one else can ever tell me what i am capable of.

It is ironic. During the revolutionary war anyone and everyone could join up. Now days, we have advanced medical treatments for practically everything and my freedom has been taken away. If there was ever a time for a diabetic to serve and live a long life it is now. It makes no logical sense, which goes against everything the military organized around (logic). Oh well. I will either win the legal battle, or be cured within 3 years and then sign up for the Army. If not, then it looks like I may be serving in the military of another country. i am a warrior at heart and mind and will die for those who are loyal to their people and loyal to freedom.

Report Inappropriate Content

most of the people with T1 in the revolutionary war would have died before they got to fighting age.  While I know (first hand) that adults can get T1, it is still less of a percentage than juvenile.. and without statistics to back me,I believe it has increased over the years.  



You go to school to learn, not for a report card.
You use your meter to learn, not for a report card

‎10-11-2012 03:59 PM - edited ‎10-11-2012 04:12 PM

To everyone who has so far posted.   Every person  has a right to their own opinions. 

Hopefully based on facts.  I respond again after reading more posts.......

 

This quote is from a retired Battle Commander, USAF.  "The biggest barrier to diabetics serving in the military is predictability!  Fellow comrades must be able to absolutely depend upon the  immediate response from their comrades at all times.  Everyone's life depends on it!.  Even the loved ones back home"

 

There are positions within the military complex that persons with diabetes, wanting to serve, may be able to qualify to hold.   At the same time, when a crises occurs everyone must respond. 

 

An example: The Cuban [edited] Missle crises; too close to home! (Oops made that mistake, sorry.)  The military personnel knew what to do and acted immediately (no time  to test their BG).  Fighters were instantly in the air, ground troops armed and ready, their families if with them,  had been taught how to handle a crises.  I was there, I know what I saw and experienced!

 

Joan

 

 


* Type 1 Diagnosed for 57years as of Nov 2014
* 50 Year Type 1 Medalist Award from Joslin Diabetes Clinic (Harvard Medical School)
* Medtronic Paradigm Revel 523 insulin pump as of March 11, 2011
* Insulin: Humalog
* Food Allergies: milk, yeast, corn
* Hashimoto's thyroid disease
* A bit of arthritis
* One kidney due to benign Angiomyolipoma.
* Volunteer Community Disaster Co-Coordinator
* Hobbies/Interests: Wildlife Naturalists, artist, gardening, music

The original poster edited out their comment about "normal" people vs. people with diabetes, so maybe my comment is now out of context.   

 

As for diabetics fighting in the Revolutionary war... Please tell us more....

Pam

Diagnosed Type 1 at age 16 months, over 45 years now
Minimed pump and cgm since July '09. Metformin (insulin resistance), levothyroxine(thyroid), losartan (BP)
I have traveled cross country, and to Canada, UK, Kenya, Mexico, Jamaica, Equador/Galapagos islands, and lived in Egypt for a year.

‎10-11-2012 07:21 PM

Fettcha1978 wrote:

So going along that line of reasoning then we would have lost the revolutionary war because diabetics would have been dropping like flies and effecting others. So it is even more amazing we won our almost freedom.

ummmmm insulin wasn't discovered until 1922.... which would be after ww1......  sooo yeah pretty much i can guarentee they weren't shooting muskets..... once dx'd you were withering away to nothing from the "pissing evile"...

i understand your gunghoenessbut you have to worry about more than your ship sinking though.....

 

like oops i just dropped my last months supply of insulin and the vial shattered on the floor...... it isn't like you can say 'hey cap'n turn this burg round'.......

 

also while in intense situations like say running into pirates as an officer you are responsible for others... stress and thinking cause your brain to exercise and can cause a hypo which affects the decisions  you make for your men..... again it is more than you saying i got this.....




_________________________________________________________________________________

Type 1 dx. on 7-26-07......enjoying every bonus moment insulin allows, even the painful ones......

‎10-11-2012 07:34 PM - edited ‎10-11-2012 07:37 PM

and also please undetsand no one is taking away your 'freedoms'.... it isn't mandatory you serve that being said since it is not mandatory you cannot also mandate the rules for which they accept volunteers.... it is of the volunteer military to decide what type of volunteers they will accept.....

 

they say no to type1 i accept it and agree with it...  that being said that doesn't stop you from having the freedom to choose to apply for another job elsewhere.. and also in doing soo those companies or organization can elect to choose whom they want to deal with....

 

our "freedom" is the freedom to choose but that being said it leaves the other party up to choose as well and when both can come to a mutual agreement they do, when they cannot they don't....   but that is your freedom.... that is what my military has fought for....

 

you have to understand the freedom to choose cuts both ways....

 

 




_________________________________________________________________________________

Type 1 dx. on 7-26-07......enjoying every bonus moment insulin allows, even the painful ones......
